section.heading: Cases in which receiver may be appointed.

content.p: In an action by a vendor to vacate a fraudulent purchase of property, or by a creditor to subject any property or fund to the creditorï¿½s claim, or between partners or others jointly owning or interested in any property or fund, on application of the plaintiff, or of any party whose right to or interest in the property or fund, or the proceeds thereof, is probable, and where it is shown that the property or fund is in danger of being lost, removed or materially injured. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In an action by a mortgagee for the foreclosure of the mortgage and sale of the mortgaged property, where it appears that the mortgaged property is in danger of being lost, removed or materially injured, or that the condition of the mortgage has not been performed, and that the property is probably insufficient to discharge the mortgage debt. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
After judgment, to carry the judgment into effect. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

After judgment, to dispose of the property according to the judgment, or to preserve it during the pendency of an appeal, or in proceedings in aid of execution, when an execution has been returned unsatisfied, or when the judgment debtor refuses to apply the judgment debtorï¿½s property in satisfaction of the judgment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In the cases when a corporation has been dissolved, or is insolvent, or in imminent danger of insolvency, or has forfeited its corporate rights. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In all other cases where receivers have heretofore been appointed by the usages of the courts of equity.

authorialNote.p: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ [1911 CPA ï¿½ 251; RL ï¿½ 5193; NCL ï¿½ 8749]

section.heading: Additional cases in which receiver may be appointed.

content.p: In addition to the cases enumerated inNRS 32.010, a court or judge may appoint a receiver in an action brought by a secured lender to enforce the right provided inNRS 40.507, or a similar right provided in a mortgage, to enter and inspect real collateral to determine the existence, location, nature and magnitude of any past, present or threatened release or presence of a hazardous substance from, in, into or onto it. A right provided in a mortgage is subject to the same limitations and requirement of notice as are provided inNRS 40.507. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½hazardous substance,ï¿½ ï¿½releaseï¿½ and ï¿½secured lenderï¿½ have the meanings ascribed to them inNRS 40.504,40.505and40.506, respectively.

section.heading: Reversion and disposition of unclaimed dividends in receivership.

content.p: In any receivership proceeding instituted in which a dividend has been declared and ordered paid to creditors, any dividend which remains unclaimed for 3 years reverts to the general fund of the estate and must be applied as follows: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To the payment of costs and expenses of the administration of the estate and receivership. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

To a new dividend distributed to creditors whose claims have been allowed but not paid in full. After those claims have been paid in full, the balance is presumed abandoned underchapter 120Aof NRS. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
This section applies to any receivership proceeding which may be brought, and includes any bank, banking corporation, corporation, copartnership, company, association or natural person.
NRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, may be cited as the Uniform Commercial Real Estate Receivership Act.
As used inNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, unless the context otherwise requires, the words and terms defined inNRS 32.110to32.215, inclusive, have the meanings ascribed to them in those sections.
With respect to an individual: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A companion of the individual; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A lineal ancestor or descendant, whether by blood or adoption, of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The individual; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A companion of the individual; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A companion of an ancestor or descendant described in paragraph
; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A sibling, aunt, uncle, great aunt, great uncle, first cousin, niece, nephew, grandniece, or grandnephew of the individual, whether related by the whole or the half blood or adoption, or a companion of any of them; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other individual occupying the residence of the individual; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
With respect to a person other than an individual: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An officer, director, manager, member, partner, employee or trustee or other fiduciary of the person; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A companion of, or an individual occupying the residence of, an individual described in paragraph
or
The spouse of an individual; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The domestic partner, as defined inNRS 122A.030, of an individual; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Another individual in a civil union with an individual.
ï¿½Courtï¿½ means a district court of this State.

ï¿½Executory contractï¿½ means a contract, including a lease, under which each party has an unperformed obligation and the failure of a party to complete performance would constitute a material breach.
ï¿½Governmental unitï¿½ means an office, department, division, bureau, board, commission or other agency of this State or a subdivision of this State.
ï¿½Lienï¿½ means an interest in property which secures payment or performance of an obligation.
ï¿½Mortgageï¿½ means a record, however denominated, that creates or provides for a consensual lien on real property or rents, even if it also creates or provides for a lien on personal property.
ï¿½Mortgageeï¿½ means a person entitled to enforce an obligation secured by a mortgage.
ï¿½Mortgagorï¿½ means a person that grants a mortgage or a successor in ownership of the real property described in the mortgage.
ï¿½Ownerï¿½ means the person for whose property a receiver is appointed.
ï¿½Personï¿½ means an individual, estate, business or nonprofit entity, public corporation, government or governmental subdivision, agency or instrumentality, or other legal entity.

To the extent of the value of receivership property, claims arising out of the loss, nonconformity or interference with the use of, defects or infringement of rights in or damage to the property; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

To the extent of the value of receivership property and to the extent payable to the owner or mortgagee, insurance payable by reason of the loss or nonconformity of, defects or infringement of rights in or damage to the property.

ï¿½Propertyï¿½ means all of a personï¿½s right, title and interest, both legal and equitable, in real and personal property, tangible and intangible, wherever located and however acquired. The term includes proceeds, products, offspring, rents or profits of or from the property.

ï¿½Receiverï¿½ means a person appointed by the court as the courtï¿½s agent, and subject to the courtï¿½s direction, to take possession of, manage and, if authorized byNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, or court order, transfer, sell, lease, license, exchange, collect or otherwise dispose of receivership property.
ï¿½Receivershipï¿½ means a proceeding in which a receiver is appointed.

ï¿½Receivership propertyï¿½ means the property of an owner that is described in the order appointing a receiver or a subsequent order. The term includes any proceeds, products, offspring, rents or profits of or from the property.
ï¿½Record,ï¿½ used as a noun, means information that is inscribed on a tangible medium or that is stored on an electronic or other medium and is retrievable in perceivable form.
Sums payable for the right to possess or occupy, or for the actual possession or occupation of, real property of another person; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Claims arising out of a default in the payment of sums payable for the right to possess or occupy real property of another person; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Sums payable to a mortgagor for payment or reimbursement of expenses incurred in owning, operating and maintaining real property or constructing or installing improvements on real property; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Other sums payable under an agreement relating to the real property of another person that constitute rents under law of this State other thanNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive.
ï¿½Secured obligationï¿½ means an obligation the payment or performance of which is secured by a security agreement.
ï¿½Security agreementï¿½ means an agreement that creates or provides for a lien.
Execute or adopt a tangible symbol; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Attach to or logically associate with the record an electronic sound, symbol or process.

ï¿½Stateï¿½ means a state of the United States, the District of Columbia, Puerto Rico, the United States Virgin Islands or any territory or insular possession subject to the jurisdiction of the United States.

Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2 or 3,NRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, apply to a receivership for an interest in real property and any personal property related to or used in operating the real property. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ 2.NRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, do not apply to a receivership for an interest in real property improved by one to four dwelling units unless: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The interest is used for agricultural, commercial, industrial or mineral-extraction purposes, other than incidental uses by an owner occupying the property as the ownerï¿½s primary residence; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The interest secures an obligation incurred at a time when the property was used or planned for use for agricultural, commercial, industrial or mineral-extraction purposes; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The owner planned or is planning to develop the property into one or more dwelling units to be sold or leased in the ordinary course of the ownerï¿½s business; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The owner is collecting or has the right to collect rents or other income from the property from a person other than an affiliate of the owner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ 3.NRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, do not apply to a receivership authorized by law of this State other thanNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, in which the receiver is a governmental unit or an individual acting in an official capacity on behalf of the unit except to the extent provided by the other law. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ 4.NRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, do not limit the authority of a court to appoint a receiver under law of this State other thanNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Unless displaced by a particular provision ofNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, the principles of law and equity supplement the provisions ofNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive.

Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, the court may issue an order underNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, only after notice and opportunity for a hearing appropriate in the circumstances. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The court may issue an order underNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
After notice and without a prior hearing if the circumstances require issuance of an order before a hearing is held; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
After notice and without a hearing if no interested party timely requests a hearing.

The court that appoints a receiver underNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, has exclusive jurisdiction to direct the receiver and determine any controversy related to the receivership or receivership property.
The court may appoint a receiver: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Before judgment, to protect a party that demonstrates an apparent right, title or interest in real property that is the subject of the action, if the property or its revenue-producing potential: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is being subjected to or is in danger of waste, loss, dissipation or impairment; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
After judgment: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To carry the judgment into effect; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To preserve nonexempt real property pending appeal or when an execution has been returned unsatisfied and the owner refuses to apply the property in satisfaction of the judgment; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In an action in which a receiver for real property may be appointed on equitable grounds; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
During the time allowed for redemption, to preserve real property sold in an execution or foreclosure sale and secure its rents to the person entitled to the rents. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
In connection with the foreclosure or other enforcement of a mortgage, a mortgagee is entitled to appointment of a receiver for the mortgaged property if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The owner fails to turn over to the mortgagee proceeds or rents the mortgagee was entitled to collect; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The holder of a subordinate lien obtains appointment of a receiver for the property. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The court may condition appointment of a receiver without prior notice under paragraph
of subsection 2 ofNRS 32.250or without a prior hearing under paragraph

of subsection 2 ofNRS 32.250on the giving of security by the person seeking the appointment for the payment of damages, reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees and costs incurred or suffered by any person if the court later concludes that the appointment was not justified. If the court later concludes that the appointment was justified, the court shall release the security.

section.heading: Disqualification from appointment as receiver; disclosure of interest.

content.p: The court may not appoint a person as receiver unless the person submits to the court a statement under penalty of perjury that the person is not disqualified. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Except as otherwise provided in subsection 3, a person is disqualified from appointment as receiver if the person: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is an affiliate of a party; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has a material financial interest in the outcome of the action, other than compensation the court may allow the receiver; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Has a debtor-creditor relationship with a party; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Holds an equity interest in a party, other than a noncontrolling interest in a publicly traded company. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person is not disqualified from appointment as receiver solely because the person: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Was appointed receiver or is owed compensation in an unrelated matter involving a party or was engaged by a party in a matter unrelated to the receivership; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is an individual obligated to a party on a debt that is not in default and was incurred primarily for personal, family or household purposes; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Maintains with a party a deposit account as defined in paragraph (ff) of subsection 1 ofNRS 104.9102. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person seeking appointment of a receiver may nominate a person to serve as receiver, but the court is not bound by the nomination.

section.heading: Adoption of rules governing ethics of receivers.

content.p: The Supreme Court shall adopt rules: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Governing the ethics and independence of receivers; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Preventing self-dealing by a receiver. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½self-dealingï¿½ means any direct or indirect: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Payment of compensation, or payment or reimbursement of expenses, by a receivership to the receiver; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Transfer to, or use by or for the benefit of, a receiver of the income or assets of the receivership.
Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, a receiver shall post with the court a bond that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is in an amount the court specifies; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Is effective as of the date of the receiverï¿½s appointment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The court may approve the posting by a receiver with the court of alternative security, such as a letter of credit or deposit of funds. The receiver may not use receivership property as alternative security. Interest that accrues on deposited funds must be paid to the receiver on the receiverï¿½s discharge. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The court may authorize a receiver to act before the receiver posts the bond or alternative security required by this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A claim against a receiverï¿½s bond or alternative security must be made not later than 6 months after the date the receiver is discharged.

section.heading: Status of receiver as lien creditor.

content.p: On appointment of a receiver, the receiver has the status of a lien creditor under: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ 1.NRS 104.9101to104.9717, inclusive, as to receivership property that is personal property or fixtures; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ 2.NRS 111.310to111.3655, inclusive, as to receivership property that is real property.

section.heading: Security agreement covering property acquired after appointment of receiver.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided by law of this State other thanNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, property that a receiver or owner acquires after appointment of the receiver is subject to a security agreement entered into before the appointment to the same extent as if the court had not appointed the receiver.

section.heading: Collection and turnover of receivership property.

content.p: Unless the court orders otherwise, on demand by a receiver: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A person that owes a debt that is receivership property and is matured or payable on demand or on order shall pay the debt to or on the order of the receiver, except to the extent the debt is subject to setoff or recoupment; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Subject to subsection 3, a person that has possession, custody or control of receivership property shall turn the property over to the receiver. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person that has notice of the appointment of a receiver and owes a debt that is receivership property may not satisfy the debt by payment to the owner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a creditor has possession, custody or control of receivership property and the validity, perfection or priority of the creditorï¿½s lien on the property depends on the creditorï¿½s possession, custody or control, the creditor may retain possession, custody or control until the court orders adequate protection of the creditorï¿½s lien. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Unless a bona fide dispute exists about a receiverï¿½s right to possession, custody or control of receivership property, the court may sanction as civil contempt a personï¿½s failure to turn the property over when required by this section.
Except as limited by court order or law of this State other thanNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, a receiver may: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Operate a business constituting receivership property, including preservation, use, sale, lease, license, exchange, collection or disposition of the property in the ordinary course of business; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

In the ordinary course of business, incur unsecured debt and pay expenses incidental to the receiverï¿½s preservation, use, sale, lease, license, exchange, collection or disposition of receivership property; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Seek and obtain instruction from the court concerning receivership property, exercise of the receiverï¿½s powers and performance of the receiverï¿½s duties; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

On subpoena, compel a person to submit to examination under oath, or to produce and permit inspection and copying of designated records or tangible things, with respect to receivership property or any other matter that may affect administration of the receivership; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Engage a professional as provided inNRS 32.310; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Apply to a court of another state for appointment as ancillary receiver with respect to receivership property located in that state; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Exercise any power conferred by court order,NRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, or law of this State other thanNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
With court approval, a receiver may: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Make improvements to receivership property; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Pay compensation to the receiver as provided inNRS 32.340, and to each professional engaged by the receiver as provided inNRS 32.310; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Recommend allowance or disallowance of a claim of a creditor as provided inNRS 32.335; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Make a distribution of receivership property as provided inNRS 32.335. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A receiver shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Prepare and retain appropriate business records, including a record of each receipt, disbursement and disposition of receivership property; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Account for receivership property, including the proceeds of a sale, lease, license, exchange, collection or other disposition of the property; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Record in the office of the county recorder of the county in which the receivership is administered and in the office of the county recorder of every county in which any real property of the receivership is located a copy of the order appointing the receiver and, if a legal description of the real property is not included in the order, the legal description; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Disclose to the court any fact arising during the receivership which would disqualify the receiver underNRS 32.265; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Perform any duty imposed by court order,NRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, or law of this State other thanNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The powers and duties of a receiver may be expanded, modified or limited by court order.
An owner shall: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Identify all records and other information relating to the receivership property, including a password, authorization or other information needed to obtain or maintain access to or control of the receivership property, and make available to the receiver the records and information in the ownerï¿½s possession, custody or control; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

On subpoena, submit to examination under oath by the receiver concerning the acts, conduct, property, liabilities and financial condition of the owner or any matter relating to the receivership property or the receivership; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Perform any duty imposed by court order,NRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, or law of this State other thanNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If an owner is a person other than an individual, this section applies to each officer, director, manager, member, partner, trustee or other person exercising or having the power to exercise control over the affairs of the owner. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If a person knowingly fails to perform a duty imposed by this section, the court may: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Award the receiver actual damages caused by the personï¿½s failure, reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees and costs; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Sanction the failure as civil contempt.
Except as otherwise provided in subsection 4 or ordered by the court, an order appointing a receiver operates as a stay, applicable to all persons, of an act, action or proceeding: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To obtain possession of, exercise control over or enforce a judgment against receivership property; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
To enforce a lien against receivership property to the extent the lien secures a claim against the owner which arose before entry of the order. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in subsection 4, the court may enjoin an act, action or proceeding against or relating to receivership property if the injunction is necessary to protect the property or facilitate administration of the receivership. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person whose act, action or proceeding is stayed or enjoined under this section may apply to the court for relief from the stay or injunction for cause. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
An order under subsection 1 or 2 does not operate as a stay or injunction of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Commencement or continuation of an action or proceeding, or enforcement of a judgment other than a money judgment in an action or proceeding, by a governmental unit to enforce its police or regulatory power; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Establishment by a governmental unit of a tax liability against the owner or receivership property or an appeal of the liability. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The court may void an act that violates a stay or injunction under this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If a person knowingly violates a stay or injunction under this section, the court may: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Award actual damages caused by the violation, reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees and costs; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Sanction the violation as civil contempt.

With court approval, a receiver may engage an attorney, accountant, appraiser, auctioneer, broker or other professional to assist the receiver in performing a duty or exercising a power of the receiver. The receiver shall disclose to the court: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any potential conflict of interest; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The proposed compensation. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A person is not disqualified from engagement under this section solely because of the personï¿½s engagement by, representation of or other relationship with the receiver, a creditor or a party.NRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, do not prevent the receiver from serving in the receivership as an attorney, accountant, auctioneer or broker when authorized by law. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A receiver or professional engaged under subsection 1 shall file with the court an itemized statement of the time spent, work performed and billing rate of each person that performed the work and an itemized list of expenses. The receiver shall pay the amount approved by the court.

section.heading: Use or transfer of receivership property not in ordinary course of business.

content.p: With court approval, a receiver may use receivership property other than in the ordinary course of business. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

With court approval, a receiver may transfer receivership property other than in the ordinary course of business by sale, lease, license, exchange or other disposition. Unless the agreement of sale provides otherwise, a sale under this section is free and clear of a lien of the person that obtained appointment of the receiver, any subordinate lien and any right of redemption but is subject to a senior lien. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A lien on receivership property which is extinguished by a transfer under subsection 2 attaches to the proceeds of the transfer with the same validity, perfection and priority the lien had on the property immediately before the transfer, even if the proceeds are not sufficient to satisfy all obligations secured by the lien. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A transfer under subsection 2 may occur by means other than a public auction sale. A creditor holding a valid lien on the property to be transferred may purchase the property and offset against the purchase price part or all of the allowed amount secured by the lien, if the creditor tenders funds sufficient to satisfy in full the reasonable expenses of transfer and the obligation secured by any senior lien extinguished by the transfer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A reversal or modification of an order approving a transfer under subsection 2 does not affect the validity of the transfer to a person that acquired the property in good faith or revive against the person any lien extinguished by the transfer, whether the person knew before the transfer of the request for reversal or modification, unless the court stayed the order before the transfer. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
As used in this section, ï¿½good faithï¿½ means honesty in fact and the observance of reasonable commercial standards of fair dealing.

Except as otherwise provided in subsection 7, with court approval, a receiver may adopt or reject an executory contract of the owner relating to receivership property. The court may condition the receiverï¿½s adoption and continued performance of the contract on terms appropriate under the circumstances. If the receiver does not request court approval to adopt or reject the contract within a reasonable time after the receiverï¿½s appointment, the receiver is deemed to have rejected the contract. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A receiverï¿½s performance of an executory contract before court approval under subsection 1 of its adoption or rejection is not an adoption of the contract and does not preclude the receiver from seeking approval to reject the contract. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A provision in an executory contract which requires or permits a forfeiture, modification or termination of the contract because of the appointment of a receiver or the financial condition of the owner does not affect a receiverï¿½s power under subsection 1 to adopt the contract. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A receiverï¿½s right to possess or use receivership property pursuant to an executory contract terminates on rejection of the contract under subsection 1. Rejection is a breach of the contract effective immediately before appointment of the receiver. A claim for damages for rejection of the contract must be submitted by the later of: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The time set for submitting a claim in the receivership; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Thirty days after the court approves the rejection. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If, at the time a receiver is appointed, the owner has the right to assign an executory contract relating to receivership property under law of this State other thanNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, the receiver may assign the contract with court approval. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a receiver rejects under subsection 1 an executory contract for the sale of receivership property that is real property in possession of the purchaser or a real-property timeshare interest, the purchaser may: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Treat the rejection as a termination of the contract, and in that case the purchaser has a lien on the property for the recovery of any part of the purchase price the purchaser paid; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Retain the purchaserï¿½s right to possession under the contract, and in that case the purchaser shall continue to perform all obligations arising under the contract and may offset any damages caused by nonperformance of an obligation of the owner after the date of the rejection, but the purchaser has no right or claim against other receivership property or the receiver on account of the damages. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A receiver may not reject an unexpired lease of real property under which the owner is the landlord if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The receiver was appointed at the request of a person other than a mortgagee; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The receiver was appointed at the request of a mortgagee and: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The tenant has an enforceable agreement with the mortgagee or the holder of a senior lien under which the tenantï¿½s occupancy will not be disturbed as long as the tenant performs its obligations under the lease; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The mortgagee has consented to the lease, either in a signed record or by its failure timely to object that the lease violated the mortgage; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The terms of the lease were commercially reasonable at the time the lease was agreed to and the tenant did not know or have reason to know that the lease violated the mortgage. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

As used in this section, ï¿½timeshare interestï¿½ means an interest having a duration of more than 3 years which grants its holder the right to use and occupy an accommodation, facility or recreational site, whether improved or not, for a specific period less than a full year during any given year.

A receiver is entitled to all defenses and immunities provided by law of this State other thanNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, for an act or omission within the scope of the receiverï¿½s appointment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A receiver may be sued personally for an act or omission in administering receivership property only with approval of the court that appointed the receiver.
Fees and expenses of the receiver and, if not filed separately, a request for approval of payment of the fees and expenses; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other information required by the court.

section.heading: Notice of appointment; claim against receivership; distribution to creditors.

content.p: Except as otherwise provided in subsection 6, a receiver shall give notice of appointment of the receiver to creditors of the owner by: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Deposit for delivery through first-class mail or other commercially reasonable delivery method to the last known address of each creditor; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Publication as directed by the court. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in subsection 6, the notice required by subsection 1 must specify the date by which each creditor holding a claim against the owner which arose before appointment of the receiver must submit the claim to the receiver. The date specified must be at least 90 days after the later of notice under paragraph
of subsection 1 or last publication under paragraph

of subsection 1. The court may extend the period for submitting the claim. Unless the court orders otherwise, a claim that is not submitted timely is not entitled to a distribution from the receivership. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A claim submitted by a creditor under this section must: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
State the name and address of the creditor; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
State the amount and basis of the claim; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Identify any property securing the claim; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Be signed by the creditor under penalty of perjury; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Include a copy of any record on which the claim is based. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

An assignment by a creditor of a claim against the owner is effective against the receiver only if the assignee gives timely notice of the assignment to the receiver in a signed record. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

At any time before entry of an order approving a receiverï¿½s final report, the receiver may file with the court an objection to a claim of a creditor, stating the basis for the objection. The court shall allow or disallow the claim according to law of this State other thanNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the court concludes that receivership property is likely to be insufficient to satisfy claims of each creditor holding a perfected lien on the property, the court may order that: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The receiver need not give notice under subsection 1 of the appointment to all creditors of the owner, but only such creditors as the court directs; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Unsecured creditors need not submit claims under this section. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Subject toNRS 32.340: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

A distribution of receivership property to a creditor holding a perfected lien on the property must be made in accordance with the creditorï¿½s priority under law of this State other thanNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A distribution of receivership property to a creditor with an allowed unsecured claim must be made as the court directs according to law of this State other thanNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive.

The court may award a receiver from receivership property the reasonable and necessary fees and expenses of performing the duties of the receiver and exercising the powers of the receiver. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The court may order one or more of the following to pay the reasonable and necessary fees and expenses of the receivership, including reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees and costs: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person that requested the appointment of the receiver, if the receivership does not produce sufficient funds to pay the fees and expenses; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A person whose conduct justified or would have justified the appointment of the receiver under paragraph
of subsection 1 ofNRS 32.260.

section.heading: Removal of receiver; replacement; termination of receivership.

content.p: The court may remove a receiver for cause. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The court shall replace a receiver that dies, resigns or is removed. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If the court finds that a receiver that resigns or is removed, or the representative of a receiver that is deceased, has accounted fully for and turned over to the successor receiver all receivership property and has filed a report of all receipts and disbursements during the service of the replaced receiver, the replaced receiver is discharged. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

The court may discharge a receiver and terminate the courtï¿½s administration of the receivership property if the court finds that appointment of the receiver was improvident or that the circumstances no longer warrant continuation of the receivership. If the court finds that the appointment was sought wrongfully or in bad faith, the court may assess against the person that sought the appointment: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The fees and expenses of the receivership, including reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees and costs; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Actual damages caused by the appointment, including reasonable attorneyï¿½s fees and costs.
On completion of a receiverï¿½s duties, the receiver shall file a final report including: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
A list of receivership property at the commencement of the receivership and any receivership property received during the receivership; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If not filed separately, a request for approval of the payment of fees and expenses of the receiver; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Any other information required by the court. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
If the court approves a final report filed under subsection 1 and the receiver distributes all receivership property, the receiver is discharged.

section.heading: Receivership in another state; ancillary proceeding.

content.p: The court may appoint a receiver appointed in another state, or that personï¿½s nominee, as an ancillary receiver with respect to property located in this State or subject to the jurisdiction of the court for which a receiver could be appointed underNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, if: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The person or nominee would be eligible to serve as receiver underNRS 32.265; and ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The appointment furthers the personï¿½s possession, custody, control or disposition of property subject to the receivership in the other state. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
The court may issue an order that gives effect to an order entered in another state appointing or directing a receiver. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Unless the court orders otherwise, an ancillary receiver appointed under subsection 1 has the rights, powers and duties of a receiver appointed underNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive.

A request by a mortgagee for the appointment of a receiver, the appointment of a receiver or the application by a mortgagee of receivership property or proceeds to the secured obligation does not: ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Make the mortgagee an agent of the owner; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Make the secured obligation unenforceable; ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½
Constitute an action within the meaning of subsection 1 ofNRS 40.430; or ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

Except as otherwise provided in subsection 2, bar a deficiency judgment pursuant to law of this State other thanNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, governing or relating to a deficiency judgment. ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½ï¿½

If a receiver sells receivership property that pursuant to subsection 2 ofNRS 32.315is free and clear of a lien, the ability of a creditor to enforce an obligation that had been secured by the lien is subject to law of this State other thanNRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, relating to a deficiency judgment.

In applying and construing the Uniform Commercial Real Estate Receivership Act, consideration must be given to the need to promote uniformity of the law with respect to its subject matter among states that enact it.

section.heading: Relation to Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act.

content.p: NRS 32.100to32.370, inclusive, modify, limit and supersede the Electronic Signatures in Global and National Commerce Act, 15 U.S.C. ï¿½ï¿½ 7001 et seq., but do not modify, limit or supersede Section 101(c) of that act, 15 U.S.C. ï¿½ 7001(c), or authorize electronic delivery of any of the notices described in Section 103(b) of that act, 15 U.S.C. ï¿½ 7003(b).
